Text: In a time not too far away, there was a man named John who had a weird job. He was a memory seller, trading pieces of old memories like toys. In this world, memories could be bought and sold, packed into small boxes to be used.

John's office was very high, with glass walls that let him see the whole city below. The streets were busy with people going about their day, not knowing that parts of their lives were being traded like toys.

One day, a lady came into his office. She looked sad but brave. "I want to sell my memories," she said. Her name was Lily, and she had a sad story. She wanted to forget, to make the hurt go away.

As he listened to her story, John felt bad. Was it okay to take away someone's past? To take away what makes them, them? But this was his job, so he did what he always did - he made the trade.

Days turned into weeks, then months. Business was good as more and more people wanted to buy happy memories or sell sad ones. But, each trade made John feel sadder than before.

One night, he found a memory box on his desk. He wanted to know whose life was inside. When he saw the memories, he knew they were Lily's. He felt very sad as he saw her pain, her loss, her sadness.

That night, John couldn't sleep. His dreams were filled with Lily's memories, her sadness becoming his. He woke up scared, understanding what he was really doing. He was not just a seller; he was messing with people's lives without thinking about what could happen.

The next morning, John looked at the busy city below from his office window. Each person down there was a mix of happy, sad, love, and loss. Their memories were not just toys; they were what made them, them.

With a new plan, John decided to change his business. Instead of buying and selling memories, he would help people deal with their pasts, learn from them, and get better. After all, our memories, good or bad, make us who we are.

And so, John started a new journey, leaving behind his days as a memory seller. He learned that while memories can hurt, they also remind us of how strong we are, our ability to get better, and our ability to find hope when we are sad.

In a time not too far away, there was a man named John who had a peculiar job. He was a memory broker, dealing in fragments of past recollections much like one would trade antique treasures. In this world, memories could be bought and sold, encapsulated in tiny,精致的盒子，被人们用来填补内心的空虚或逃避现实的痛苦。

John的办公室位于一座摩天大楼的顶层，透过落地窗可以俯瞰整个城市的繁华景象。街道上人来人往，熙熙攘攘，没有人知道，他们生活中的某些片段正被像商品一样交易着。

一天，一位女士走进了他的办公室。她看起来既悲伤又坚强。“我想卖掉我的记忆，”她说道。她的名字叫莉莉，有着一段令人心痛的故事。她渴望遗忘，希望那些伤害能够消失无踪。

听着她的故事，John内心感到沉重。这样做是否正确？剥夺一个人的过去，是否等于剥夺了造就他们个性的基石？然而，这毕竟是他的工作，所以他照常进行了交易。

日子一天天过去，转眼间几个月过去了。生意兴隆，越来越多的人想要购买快乐的记忆或者出售痛苦的回忆。但每一次交易，都让John的心更加沉重。

一天晚上，他发现办公桌上有一个记忆盒。出于好奇，他打开了它，里面装的是莉莉的记忆。看着那些画面，他感受到了她的痛苦、她的失落和她的悲伤。那一晚，John辗转难眠，梦境中充满了莉莉的回忆，她的悲伤似乎也成为了他的负担。醒来时，他感到恐惧，开始意识到自己所从事的工作实际上是在干预人们的内心世界，而他从未真正思考过这可能带来的后果。

第二天早上，站在办公室的窗前，望着楼下忙碌的人群，John意识到每个人都是由喜怒哀乐编织而成的复杂个体。他们的记忆不仅仅是可以随意交易的商品，更是塑造他们个性和身份的核心。

于是，John决定改变自己的业务方向。他不再买卖记忆，而是决心帮助人们处理过去的伤痛，从中学习并成长。毕竟，无论是好是坏，我们的记忆定义了我们是谁，以及我们如何成为今天的自己。

从此，John开始了新的旅程，告别了他曾熟悉的记忆交易行业。他明白，虽然记忆可能会带来痛苦，但它们同时也提醒我们自身的坚韧、学习与适应的能力，以及在逆境中寻找希望的勇气。
